title: When was the first permanent settlement in Sri Lanka? - Quora

response.answer_text: The first hominins may have arrived in Sri Lanka between 125,000 and 75,000 years ago, a date that is relatively late in time compared to the appearance of early modern humans in other regions of the Old World. The analysis of the dentition from three ethnic groups of Sri Lanka—the Sinhala, Tamils, and the Vedda (Hawkey, 2002). Hawkey reported that the Vedda share more similarities with the early hunter‐gatherers of the island than the Sinhalese or the Tamils https://www.researchgate.net/publication/301336596_The_Peopling_of_Sri_Lanka_from_Prehistoric_to_Historic_Times_Biological_and_Archaeological_Evidence [accessed Oct 25 2020].

Sri Lankan civulization is probably older than the Aryan civilization in India. Aryan folklore has recognized that the island of Sri Lanka, called ““Lanka" in Sanskrit, had existed when Aryans had settled in the Indo Gangetic plains. There are references to human settlements in Sri Lanka in these folklores. This leads us to believe that permanent human settlements in Sri Lanka may date back to the times of the Dravidian civilizations of Moenjodaro etc or more or less thereabouts. This may be 6,000 years ago or even somewhat earlier.

According to written history, King Pandukabaya established settlement around Anuradhapura in 437 BCE , but according to Archaeological evidence first settlements of new stone age man had been there from 48000- to 4000 BCE in Sri Lanka in the hills of Southern Sri Lanka,
